name: Secure Sockets Layer
summary: A cryptographic protocol for securing network communication, predecessor of TLS. SSL provides encryption, integrity, and authentication but is now considered deprecated in favor of TLS.
purpose: Secure data transmission over networks, providing confidentiality, integrity, and authentication

handshake.description: SSL handshake is similar to TLS, involving version negotiation, key exchange, and authentication.
steps: Step 1: ClientHello – client proposes SSL version, cipher suites, and sends random number.
Step 2: ServerHello – server selects version, cipher suite, and sends certificate.
Step 3: Key Exchange – client and server exchange keying material.
Step 4: Finished – handshake completion and secure session established.

fields.name: Record Header
fields.description: Contains content type, version, and length of the SSL record

fields.name: Handshake Messages
fields.description: Exchanged messages during handshake (ClientHello, ServerHello, Certificate, Finished, etc.)

fields.name: Ciphertext
fields.description: Encrypted application data using negotiated cipher

structure.payload: Handshake messages or encrypted application data

pitfalls: SSL 2.0 and 3.0 are deprecated and insecure
Should be replaced by TLS in all modern applications
